DOC.HEAD: Eds: DELETES item on Lee Van Cleef, which was in an earlier PM-Deaths column; No separates moved for PMs
DOC.TEXT: Soedjatmoko, the former rector of the United Nations University, died Thursday after suffering a stroke in Jogjakarta, Central Java. He was 77. Before heading the university, Soedjatmoko was Indonesian ambassador to the United States. The U.N. University, based in Tokyo, is a loose association of scholars who research peace issues and development worldwide.

Dwane Wallace, who guided Cessna Aircraft Co. to dominance in the light plane industry, died Thursday of a stroke at age 78. Wallace worked briefly as an engineer for Walter Beech, founder of Beech Aircraft Corp., in 1933. He assumed control at Cessna after his uncle, company founder Clyde Cessna, was forced to close by the Depression. Wallace and his attorney brother, Dwight, reopened the company in 1934 in Wichita. Clyde Cessna, who had started it in 1927, was installed as president. Dwane Wallace was general manager. The first Dwane Wallace design Cessna manufactured, the C-34, was a classic monoplane that became world reknowned as the Cessna Airmaster. Wallace relinquished his board chairmanship at Cessna in 1975, staying on as a $75,000-a-year consultant and a board member.

William W. Ray, the executive director of the William F. Harrah Foundation National Automobile Museum, died Wednesday of cancer at age 42. Ray had served as executive director of the Reno automobile museum since last year. During his 20-year career in the business he also directed operations at the Kentucky Derby Museum in Louisville, the Museum of Science and Industry in Tampa, Fla., the California State Railroad Museum in Sacramento and the Petroleum Museum in Midland, Texas. At one time, the Harrah's collection had more than 1,400 vehicles before it was sold to the Holiday Corp. The company auctioned off many of the vehicles and donated the remainder to the foundation, which now has about 225 vehicles in the downtown Reno collection.

Roger H. Hallowell, former president and chairman of Reed & Barton silver company and a decorated Navy commander, died Wednesday of a stroke at age 79. Hallowell joined Reed & Barton in 1938 as personnel director and became president in 1953. He retired in 1971, but served as chairman of the Taunton company until 1986. As the commander of a Navy PT boat squadron in the South Pacific during World War II, Hallowell was decorated with a Silver Star for directing the sinking or destruction of six enemy barges off the coasts of New Guinea in 1943. Since the early 1970s, he operated the Cruising Information Center in Salem, which advised on sailing trips anywhere in the world.
